trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: Many types of applications require background tasks that run independently of the user interface (UI).
trans-unit.target: Many types of applications require background tasks that run independently of the user interface (UI).

trans-unit.source: Examples include batch jobs, intensive processing tasks, and long running processes such as workflows.
trans-unit.target: Examples include batch jobs, intensive processing tasks, and long running processes such as workflows.

trans-unit.source: Background jobs can be executed without requiring user interaction; the application can start the job and then continue to process interactive requests from users.
trans-unit.target: Background jobs can be executed without requiring user interaction; the application can start the job and then continue to process interactive requests from users.

trans-unit.source: This can help to minimize the load on the application UI, which can improve availability and reduce interactive response times.
trans-unit.target: This can help to minimize the load on the application UI, which can improve availability and reduce interactive response times.

trans-unit.source: For example, if an application is required to generate thumbnails of images uploaded by users, it can do this as a background job and save the thumbnail to storage when complete without the user needing to wait for the process to complete.
trans-unit.target: For example, if an application is required to generate thumbnails of images uploaded by users, it can do this as a background job and save the thumbnail to storage when complete without the user needing to wait for the process to complete.

trans-unit.source: In the same way, a user placing an order can initiate a background workflow that processes the order, while the UI allows the user to continue browsing the website.
trans-unit.target: In the same way, a user placing an order can initiate a background workflow that processes the order, while the UI allows the user to continue browsing the website.

trans-unit.source: When the background job is complete, it can update the stored orders data and send an email to the user confirming the order.
trans-unit.target: When the background job is complete, it can update the stored orders data and send an email to the user confirming the order.

trans-unit.source: When considering whether to implement a task as a background job, the main criteria is whether the task can run without user interaction and without the UI needing to wait for the job to complete.
trans-unit.target: When considering whether to implement a task as a background job, the main criteria is whether the task can run without user interaction and without the UI needing to wait for the job to complete.

trans-unit.source: Tasks that require the user or the UI to wait while they are completed may not be appropriate as background jobs.
trans-unit.target: Tasks that require the user or the UI to wait while they are completed may not be appropriate as background jobs.

trans-unit.source: Types of background jobs
trans-unit.target: Types of background jobs

trans-unit.source: Background jobs typically have one or more of the following characteristics:
trans-unit.target: Background jobs typically have one or more of the following characteristics:

trans-unit.source: CPU intensive jobs such as mathematical calculations, structural model analysis, and more.
trans-unit.target: CPU intensive jobs such as mathematical calculations, structural model analysis, and more.

trans-unit.source: I/O intensive jobs such as executing a series of storage transactions or indexing files.
trans-unit.target: I/O intensive jobs such as executing a series of storage transactions or indexing files.

trans-unit.source: Batch jobs such as nightly data updates or scheduled processing.
trans-unit.target: Batch jobs such as nightly data updates or scheduled processing.

trans-unit.source: Long running workflows such as order fulfillment or provisioning services and systems.
trans-unit.target: Long running workflows such as order fulfillment or provisioning services and systems.

trans-unit.source: Sensitive data processing where the task is handed off to a more secure location for processing.
trans-unit.target: Sensitive data processing where the task is handed off to a more secure location for processing.

trans-unit.source: For example, you may not want to process sensitive data within a web role, and instead use a pattern such as [Gatekeeper](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn589793.aspx) to transfer the data to an isolated background role that has access to protected storage.
trans-unit.target: For example, you may not want to process sensitive data within a web role, and instead use a pattern such as [Gatekeeper](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn589793.aspx) to transfer the data to an isolated background role that has access to protected storage.

trans-unit.source: Triggers
trans-unit.target: Triggers

trans-unit.source: Background jobs can be initiated in several different ways.
trans-unit.target: Background jobs can be initiated in several different ways.

trans-unit.source: Effectively, all of them fall into one of the following categories:
trans-unit.target: Effectively, all of them fall into one of the following categories:

trans-unit.source: [**Event driven triggers**](#event-driven-triggers).
trans-unit.target: [**Event driven triggers**](#event-driven-triggers).

trans-unit.source: The task is started in response to an event, typically an action taken by a user or a step in a workflow.
trans-unit.target: The task is started in response to an event, typically an action taken by a user or a step in a workflow.

trans-unit.source: [**Schedule driven triggers**](#schedule-driven-triggers).
trans-unit.target: [**Schedule driven triggers**](#schedule-driven-triggers).

trans-unit.source: The task is invoked on a schedule based on a timer.
trans-unit.target: The task is invoked on a schedule based on a timer.

trans-unit.source: This may be a recurring schedule, or a one-off invocation specified for a later time
trans-unit.target: This may be a recurring schedule, or a one-off invocation specified for a later time

trans-unit.source: Event driven triggers
trans-unit.target: Event driven triggers

trans-unit.source: Event driven invocation uses a trigger to start the background task.
trans-unit.target: Event driven invocation uses a trigger to start the background task.

trans-unit.source: Examples of using event driven triggers include:
trans-unit.target: Examples of using event driven triggers include:

trans-unit.source: The UI or another job places a message in a queue.
trans-unit.target: The UI or another job places a message in a queue.

trans-unit.source: The message contains data about an action that has taken place, such as the user placing an order.
trans-unit.target: The message contains data about an action that has taken place, such as the user placing an order.

trans-unit.source: The background task listens on this queue and detects the arrival of a new message.
trans-unit.target: The background task listens on this queue and detects the arrival of a new message.

trans-unit.source: It reads the message and uses the data in it as the input to the background job.
trans-unit.target: It reads the message and uses the data in it as the input to the background job.

trans-unit.source: The UI or another job saves or updates a value in storage.
trans-unit.target: The UI or another job saves or updates a value in storage.

trans-unit.source: The background task monitors the storage and detects changes.
trans-unit.target: The background task monitors the storage and detects changes.

trans-unit.source: It reads the data and uses it as the input to the background job.
trans-unit.target: It reads the data and uses it as the input to the background job.

trans-unit.source: The UI or another job makes a request to an endpoint, such as an HTTPS URI, or an API exposed as a web service.
trans-unit.target: The UI or another job makes a request to an endpoint, such as an HTTPS URI, or an API exposed as a web service.

trans-unit.source: It passes the data required to complete the background task as part of the request.
trans-unit.target: It passes the data required to complete the background task as part of the request.

trans-unit.source: The endpoint or web service invokes the background task, which uses the data as its input.
trans-unit.target: The endpoint or web service invokes the background task, which uses the data as its input.

trans-unit.source: Typical examples of tasks suited to event driven invocation include image processing, workflows, sending information to remote services, sending email messages, provisioning new users in multi-tenant applications, and more.
trans-unit.target: Typical examples of tasks suited to event driven invocation include image processing, workflows, sending information to remote services, sending email messages, provisioning new users in multi-tenant applications, and more.

trans-unit.source: Schedule driven triggers
trans-unit.target: Schedule driven triggers

trans-unit.source: Schedule driven invocation uses a timer to start the background task.
trans-unit.target: Schedule driven invocation uses a timer to start the background task.

trans-unit.source: Examples of using schedule driven triggers include:
trans-unit.target: Examples of using schedule driven triggers include:

trans-unit.source: A timer running locally within the application or as part of the application’s operating system invokes a background task on a regular basis.
trans-unit.target: A timer running locally within the application or as part of the application’s operating system invokes a background task on a regular basis.

trans-unit.source: A timer running in a different application, or a timer service such as Azure Scheduler, sends a request to an API or web service on a regular basis.
trans-unit.target: A timer running in a different application, or a timer service such as Azure Scheduler, sends a request to an API or web service on a regular basis.

trans-unit.source: The API or web service invokes the background task.
trans-unit.target: The API or web service invokes the background task.

trans-unit.source: A separate process or application starts a timer that causes the background task to be invoked once after a specified time delay, or at a specific time.
trans-unit.target: A separate process or application starts a timer that causes the background task to be invoked once after a specified time delay, or at a specific time.

trans-unit.source: Typical examples of tasks suited to schedule driven invocation include batch processing routines such as updating related products lists for users based on their recent behavior, routine data processing tasks such as updating indexes or generating accumulated results, analyzing data for daily reports, data retention cleanup, data consistency checks, and more.
trans-unit.target: Typical examples of tasks suited to schedule driven invocation include batch processing routines such as updating related products lists for users based on their recent behavior, routine data processing tasks such as updating indexes or generating accumulated results, analyzing data for daily reports, data retention cleanup, data consistency checks, and more.

trans-unit.source: If you use a schedule driven task that must run as a single instance, be aware of the following:
trans-unit.target: If you use a schedule driven task that must run as a single instance, be aware of the following:

trans-unit.source: If the compute instance that is running the scheduler (such as a Virtual Machine using Windows Scheduled Tasks) is scaled, you will have multiple instances of the scheduler running and these could start multiple instances of the task.
trans-unit.target: If the compute instance that is running the scheduler (such as a Virtual Machine using Windows Scheduled Tasks) is scaled, you will have multiple instances of the scheduler running and these could start multiple instances of the task.

trans-unit.source: If tasks run for longer than the period between scheduler events, the scheduler may start another instance of the task while the previous one is still running.
trans-unit.target: If tasks run for longer than the period between scheduler events, the scheduler may start another instance of the task while the previous one is still running.

trans-unit.source: Returning results
trans-unit.target: Returning results

trans-unit.source: Background jobs execute asynchronously in a separate process, or even a separate location, from the UI or the process that invoked the background task.
trans-unit.target: Background jobs execute asynchronously in a separate process, or even a separate location, from the UI or the process that invoked the background task.

trans-unit.source: Ideally, background tasks are “fire and forget” operations, and their execution progress has no impact on the UI or the calling process.
trans-unit.target: Ideally, background tasks are “fire and forget” operations, and their execution progress has no impact on the UI or the calling process.

trans-unit.source: This means that the calling process does not wait for completion of the tasks, and therefore cannot automatically detect when the task ends.
trans-unit.target: This means that the calling process does not wait for completion of the tasks, and therefore cannot automatically detect when the task ends.

trans-unit.source: If you require a background task to communicate with the calling task to indicate progress or completion, you must implement a mechanism for this.
trans-unit.target: If you require a background task to communicate with the calling task to indicate progress or completion, you must implement a mechanism for this.

trans-unit.source: Some examples are:
trans-unit.target: Some examples are:

trans-unit.source: Write status indicator value to storage that is accessible to the UI or caller task, which can monitor or check this value when required.
trans-unit.target: Write status indicator value to storage that is accessible to the UI or caller task, which can monitor or check this value when required.

trans-unit.source: Other data that the background task must return to the caller can be placed into the same storage.
trans-unit.target: Other data that the background task must return to the caller can be placed into the same storage.

trans-unit.source: Establish a reply queue that the UI or caller listens on.
trans-unit.target: Establish a reply queue that the UI or caller listens on.

trans-unit.source: The background task can send messages to the queue indicating status and completion.
trans-unit.target: The background task can send messages to the queue indicating status and completion.

trans-unit.source: Data that the background task must return to the caller can be placed into the messages.
trans-unit.target: Data that the background task must return to the caller can be placed into the messages.

trans-unit.source: If you are using Azure Service Bus, you can use the **ReplyTo** and **CorrelationId** properties to implement this capability.
trans-unit.target: If you are using Azure Service Bus, you can use the **ReplyTo** and **CorrelationId** properties to implement this capability.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Correlation in Service Bus Brokered Messaging](http://www.cloudcasts.net/devguide/Default.aspx?id=13029).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Correlation in Service Bus Brokered Messaging](http://www.cloudcasts.net/devguide/Default.aspx?id=13029).

trans-unit.source: Expose an API or endpoint from the background task that the UI or caller can access to obtain status information.
trans-unit.target: Expose an API or endpoint from the background task that the UI or caller can access to obtain status information.

trans-unit.source: Data that the background task must return to the caller can be included in the response.
trans-unit.target: Data that the background task must return to the caller can be included in the response.

trans-unit.source: Have the background task call back to the UI or caller through an API to indicate status at predefined points or on completion.
trans-unit.target: Have the background task call back to the UI or caller through an API to indicate status at predefined points or on completion.

trans-unit.source: This might be through events raised locally, or through a publish and subscribe mechanism.
trans-unit.target: This might be through events raised locally, or through a publish and subscribe mechanism.

trans-unit.source: Data that the background task must return to the caller can be included in the request or event payload.
trans-unit.target: Data that the background task must return to the caller can be included in the request or event payload.

trans-unit.target: You can use Azure WebJobs to execute custom jobs as background tasks within an Azure Web Sites hosted application.

trans-unit.target: WebJobs can run scripts or executable programs within the context of your website as a continuous process, or in response to a trigger event from Azure Scheduler or external factors such as changes to storage blobs and message queues.

trans-unit.target: It allows you to manage scaling separately for each type of role.

trans-unit.source: For example, you may need more instances of a web role to support the current load, but fewer instances of the worker role that executes background tasks.
trans-unit.target: For example, you may need more instances of a web role to support the current load, but fewer instances of the worker role that executes background tasks.

trans-unit.source: Scaling background task compute instances separately from the UI roles can reduce hosting cost, while maintaining acceptable performance.
trans-unit.target: Scaling background task compute instances separately from the UI roles can reduce hosting cost, while maintaining acceptable performance.

trans-unit.source: It offloads the processing overhead for background tasks from the web role.
trans-unit.target: It offloads the processing overhead for background tasks from the web role.

trans-unit.source: The web role that provides the UI can remain responsive, and it may mean fewer instances are required to support a given volume of requests from users.
trans-unit.target: The web role that provides the UI can remain responsive, and it may mean fewer instances are required to support a given volume of requests from users.

trans-unit.source: It allows you to implement separation of concerns.

trans-unit.source: Each role type can implement a specific set of clearly defined and related tasks.
trans-unit.target: Each role type can implement a specific set of clearly defined and related tasks.

trans-unit.target: This makes designing and maintaining the code easier because there is less interdependence of code and functionality between each role.

trans-unit.source: It can help to isolate sensitive processes and data.

trans-unit.target: For example, web roles that implement the UI do not need to have access to data that is managed and controlled by a worker role.

trans-unit.source: There are several fundamental factors to consider when designing background tasks.
trans-unit.target: There are several fundamental factors to consider when designing background tasks.

trans-unit.source: The following sections discuss partitioning, conflicts, and coordination.
trans-unit.target: The following sections discuss partitioning, conflicts, and coordination.

trans-unit.source: Partitioning
trans-unit.target: Partitioning

trans-unit.source: If you decide to include background tasks within an existing compute instance (such as a website, web role, existing worker role, or virtual machine), you must consider how this will affect the quality attributes of the compute instance and the background task itself.
trans-unit.target: If you decide to include background tasks within an existing compute instance (such as a website, web role, existing worker role, or virtual machine), you must consider how this will affect the quality attributes of the compute instance and the background task itself.

trans-unit.source: These factors will help you to decide whether to co-locate the tasks with the existing compute instance, or separate them out into a separate compute instance:
trans-unit.target: These factors will help you to decide whether to co-locate the tasks with the existing compute instance, or separate them out into a separate compute instance:

trans-unit.source: **Availability**: Background tasks may not need to have the same level of availability as other parts of the application, in particular the UI and other parts directly involved in user interaction.
trans-unit.target: **Availability**: Background tasks may not need to have the same level of availability as other parts of the application, in particular the UI and other parts directly involved in user interaction.

trans-unit.source: Background tasks may be more tolerant of latency, retried connection failures, and other factors that affect availability because the operations can be queued.
trans-unit.target: Background tasks may be more tolerant of latency, retried connection failures, and other factors that affect availability because the operations can be queued.

trans-unit.source: However, there must be sufficient capacity to prevent backing up of requests that could block queues and affect the application as a whole.
trans-unit.target: However, there must be sufficient capacity to prevent backing up of requests that could block queues and affect the application as a whole.

trans-unit.source: **Scalability**: Background tasks are likely to have a different scalability requirement to the UI and the interactive parts of the application.
trans-unit.target: **Scalability**: Background tasks are likely to have a different scalability requirement to the UI and the interactive parts of the application.

trans-unit.source: Scaling the UI may be necessary to meet peaks in demand, while outstanding background tasks could be completed during less busy times by a fewer number of compute instances.
trans-unit.target: Scaling the UI may be necessary to meet peaks in demand, while outstanding background tasks could be completed during less busy times by a fewer number of compute instances.

trans-unit.source: **Resiliency**: Failure of a compute instance that just hosts background tasks may not fatally affect the application as a whole if the requests for these tasks can be queued or postponed until the task is available again.
trans-unit.target: **Resiliency**: Failure of a compute instance that just hosts background tasks may not fatally affect the application as a whole if the requests for these tasks can be queued or postponed until the task is available again.

trans-unit.source: If the compute instance and/or tasks can be restarted within an appropriate interval, users of the application may not be affected.
trans-unit.target: If the compute instance and/or tasks can be restarted within an appropriate interval, users of the application may not be affected.

trans-unit.source: **Security**: Background tasks may have different security requirements or restrictions than the UI or other parts of the application.
trans-unit.target: **Security**: Background tasks may have different security requirements or restrictions than the UI or other parts of the application.

trans-unit.source: By using a separate compute instance, you can specify a different security environment for the tasks.
trans-unit.target: By using a separate compute instance, you can specify a different security environment for the tasks.

trans-unit.source: You can also use patterns such as Gatekeeper to isolate the background compute instances from the UI in order to maximize security and separation.
trans-unit.target: You can also use patterns such as Gatekeeper to isolate the background compute instances from the UI in order to maximize security and separation.

trans-unit.source: **Performance**: You can choose the type of compute instance for background tasks to specifically match the performance requirements of the tasks.
trans-unit.target: **Performance**: You can choose the type of compute instance for background tasks to specifically match the performance requirements of the tasks.

trans-unit.source: This may mean using a less expensive compute option if the tasks do not require the same processing capabilities as the UI, or a larger instance if they require additional capacity and resources.
trans-unit.target: This may mean using a less expensive compute option if the tasks do not require the same processing capabilities as the UI, or a larger instance if they require additional capacity and resources.

trans-unit.source: **Manageability**: Background tasks may have a different development and deployment rhythm from the main application code or the UI.
trans-unit.target: **Manageability**: Background tasks may have a different development and deployment rhythm from the main application code or the UI.

trans-unit.source: Deploying them to a separate compute instance can simplify updates and versioning.
trans-unit.target: Deploying them to a separate compute instance can simplify updates and versioning.

trans-unit.source: **Cost**: Adding compute instances to execute background tasks increases hosting costs.
trans-unit.target: **Cost**: Adding compute instances to execute background tasks increases hosting costs.

trans-unit.source: You should carefully consider the trade-off between additional capacity and these extra costs.
trans-unit.target: You should carefully consider the trade-off between additional capacity and these extra costs.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Leader Election pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn568104.aspx) and [Competing Consumers pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn568101.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Leader Election pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn568104.aspx) and [Competing Consumers pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn568101.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Conflicts
trans-unit.target: Conflicts

trans-unit.source: If you have multiple instances of a background job, it is possible that they will compete for access to resources and services such as databases and storage.
trans-unit.target: If you have multiple instances of a background job, it is possible that they will compete for access to resources and services such as databases and storage.

trans-unit.source: This concurrent access can result in resource contention, which may cause conflicts in availability of the services and in the integrity of data in storage.
trans-unit.target: This concurrent access can result in resource contention, which may cause conflicts in availability of the services and in the integrity of data in storage.

trans-unit.source: Resource contention can be resolved by using a pessimistic locking approach to prevent competing instances of a task from concurrently accessing a service, or corrupting data.
trans-unit.target: Resource contention can be resolved by using a pessimistic locking approach to prevent competing instances of a task from concurrently accessing a service, or corrupting data.

trans-unit.source: Another approach to resolve conflicts is to define background tasks as a singleton, so that there is only ever one instance running.
trans-unit.target: Another approach to resolve conflicts is to define background tasks as a singleton, so that there is only ever one instance running.

trans-unit.source: However, this eliminates the reliability and performance benefits that a multiple-instance configuration could provide, especially if the UI can supply sufficient work to keep more than one background task busy.
trans-unit.target: However, this eliminates the reliability and performance benefits that a multiple-instance configuration could provide, especially if the UI can supply sufficient work to keep more than one background task busy.

trans-unit.source: It is vital to ensure that the background task can automatically restart, and that it has sufficient capacity to cope with peaks in demand.
trans-unit.target: It is vital to ensure that the background task can automatically restart, and that it has sufficient capacity to cope with peaks in demand.

trans-unit.source: This may be achieved by allocating a compute instance with sufficient resources, by implementing a queueing mechanism that can store requests for later execution when demand decreases, or by a combination of these techniques.
trans-unit.target: This may be achieved by allocating a compute instance with sufficient resources, by implementing a queueing mechanism that can store requests for later execution when demand decreases, or by a combination of these techniques.

trans-unit.source: Coordination
trans-unit.target: Coordination

trans-unit.source: The background tasks may be complex, and require multiple individual tasks to execute to produce a result or to fulfil all the requirements.
trans-unit.target: The background tasks may be complex, and require multiple individual tasks to execute to produce a result or to fulfil all the requirements.

trans-unit.source: It is common in these scenarios to divide the task into smaller discreet steps or subtasks that can be executed by multiple consumers.
trans-unit.target: It is common in these scenarios to divide the task into smaller discreet steps or subtasks that can be executed by multiple consumers.

trans-unit.source: Multi-step jobs can be more efficient and more flexible because individual steps may be reusable in multiple jobs.
trans-unit.target: Multi-step jobs can be more efficient and more flexible because individual steps may be reusable in multiple jobs.

trans-unit.source: It is also easy to add, remove, or modify the order of the steps.
trans-unit.target: It is also easy to add, remove, or modify the order of the steps.

trans-unit.source: Coordinating multiple tasks and steps can be challenging, but there are three common patterns you can use to guide your implementation of a solution:
trans-unit.target: Coordinating multiple tasks and steps can be challenging, but there are three common patterns you can use to guide your implementation of a solution:

trans-unit.source: **Decomposing a task into multiple reusable steps**.
trans-unit.target: **Decomposing a task into multiple reusable steps**.

trans-unit.source: An application may be required to perform a variety of tasks of varying complexity on the information that it processes.
trans-unit.target: An application may be required to perform a variety of tasks of varying complexity on the information that it processes.

trans-unit.source: A straightforward but inflexible approach to implementing this application could be to perform this processing as monolithic module.
trans-unit.target: A straightforward but inflexible approach to implementing this application could be to perform this processing as monolithic module.

trans-unit.source: However, this approach is likely to reduce the opportunities for refactoring the code, optimizing it, or reusing it if parts of the same processing are required elsewhere within the application.
trans-unit.target: However, this approach is likely to reduce the opportunities for refactoring the code, optimizing it, or reusing it if parts of the same processing are required elsewhere within the application.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Pipes and Filters Pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn568100.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Pipes and Filters Pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn568100.aspx).

trans-unit.source: **Managing execution of the steps for a task**.
trans-unit.target: **Managing execution of the steps for a task**.

trans-unit.source: An application may perform tasks that comprise a number of steps, some of which may invoke remote services or access remote resources.
trans-unit.target: An application may perform tasks that comprise a number of steps, some of which may invoke remote services or access remote resources.

trans-unit.source: The individual steps may be independent of each other, but they are orchestrated by the application logic that implements the task.
trans-unit.target: The individual steps may be independent of each other, but they are orchestrated by the application logic that implements the task.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Scheduler Agent Supervisor Pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn589780.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Scheduler Agent Supervisor Pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn589780.aspx).

trans-unit.source: **Managing recovery for steps of a task that fail**.
trans-unit.target: **Managing recovery for steps of a task that fail**.

trans-unit.source: An application may need to undo the work performed by a series of steps, which together define an eventually consistent operation, if one or more of the steps fail.
trans-unit.target: An application may need to undo the work performed by a series of steps, which together define an eventually consistent operation, if one or more of the steps fail.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Compensating Transaction Pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn589804.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Compensating Transaction Pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn589804.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Lifecycle (Cloud Services)
trans-unit.target: Lifecycle (Cloud Services)

trans-unit.source: If you decide to implement background jobs for Cloud Services applications that use web and worker roles by using the **RoleEntryPoint** class, it is important to understand the lifecycle of this class in order to use it correctly.
trans-unit.target: If you decide to implement background jobs for Cloud Services applications that use web and worker roles by using the **RoleEntryPoint** class, it is important to understand the lifecycle of this class in order to use it correctly.

trans-unit.source: Web and worker roles go through a set of distinct phases as they start, run, and stop.
trans-unit.target: Web and worker roles go through a set of distinct phases as they start, run, and stop.

trans-unit.source: The **RoleEntryPoint** class exposes a series of events that indicate when these stages are occurring.
trans-unit.target: The **RoleEntryPoint** class exposes a series of events that indicate when these stages are occurring.

trans-unit.source: You use these to initialize, run, and stop your custom background tasks.
trans-unit.target: You use these to initialize, run, and stop your custom background tasks.

trans-unit.source: The complete cycle is:
trans-unit.target: The complete cycle is:

trans-unit.source: Azure loads the role assembly and searches it for a class that derives from **RoleEntryPoint**.
trans-unit.target: Azure loads the role assembly and searches it for a class that derives from **RoleEntryPoint**.

trans-unit.source: If it finds this class, it calls **RoleEntryPoint.OnStart()**.
trans-unit.target: If it finds this class, it calls **RoleEntryPoint.OnStart()**.

trans-unit.source: You override this method to initialize your background tasks.
trans-unit.target: You override this method to initialize your background tasks.

trans-unit.source: After the **OnStart** method completes, Azure calls **Application_Start()** in the application’s Global file if this is present (for example, Global.asax in a web role running ASP.NET).
trans-unit.target: After the **OnStart** method completes, Azure calls **Application_Start()** in the application’s Global file if this is present (for example, Global.asax in a web role running ASP.NET).

trans-unit.source: Azure calls **RoleEntryPoint.Run()** on a new foreground thread that executes in parallel with **OnStart()**.
trans-unit.target: Azure calls **RoleEntryPoint.Run()** on a new foreground thread that executes in parallel with **OnStart()**.

trans-unit.source: You override this method to start your background tasks.
trans-unit.target: You override this method to start your background tasks.

trans-unit.source: When the Run method ends, Azure first calls **Application_End()** in the application’s Global file if this is present, and then calls **RoleEntryPoint.OnStop()**.
trans-unit.target: When the Run method ends, Azure first calls **Application_End()** in the application’s Global file if this is present, and then calls **RoleEntryPoint.OnStop()**.

trans-unit.source: You override the **OnStop** method to stop your background tasks, clean up resources, dispose of objects, and close connections that the tasks may have used.
trans-unit.target: You override the **OnStop** method to stop your background tasks, clean up resources, dispose of objects, and close connections that the tasks may have used.

trans-unit.source: The Azure worker role host process is stopped.
trans-unit.target: The Azure worker role host process is stopped.

trans-unit.source: At this point, the role will be recycled and will restart.
trans-unit.target: At this point, the role will be recycled and will restart.

trans-unit.source: Consider the following points when planning how you will run background tasks in a web or worker role:
trans-unit.target: Consider the following points when planning how you will run background tasks in a web or worker role:

trans-unit.source: The default **Run** method implementation in the **RoleEntryPoint** class contains a call to **Thread.Sleep(Timeout.Infinite)** that keeps the role alive indefinitely.
trans-unit.target: The default **Run** method implementation in the **RoleEntryPoint** class contains a call to **Thread.Sleep(Timeout.Infinite)** that keeps the role alive indefinitely.

trans-unit.source: Resiliency considerations
trans-unit.target: Resiliency considerations

trans-unit.source: Background tasks must be resilient in order to provide reliable services to the application.
trans-unit.target: Background tasks must be resilient in order to provide reliable services to the application.

trans-unit.source: When planning and designing background tasks, consider the following points:
trans-unit.target: When planning and designing background tasks, consider the following points:

trans-unit.source: Background tasks must be able to gracefully handle role or service restarts without corrupting data or introducing inconsistency into the application.
trans-unit.target: Background tasks must be able to gracefully handle role or service restarts without corrupting data or introducing inconsistency into the application.

trans-unit.source: For long-running or multi-step tasks, consider using _check pointing_ by saving the state of jobs in persistent storage, or as messages in a queue if this is appropriate.
trans-unit.target: For long-running or multi-step tasks, consider using _check pointing_ by saving the state of jobs in persistent storage, or as messages in a queue if this is appropriate.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can persist state information in a message in a queue and incrementally update this state information with the task progress so that the task can be processed from the last known good checkpoint instead of restarting from the beginning.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can persist state information in a message in a queue and incrementally update this state information with the task progress so that the task can be processed from the last known good checkpoint instead of restarting from the beginning.

trans-unit.source: When using Azure Service Bus queues, you can use message sessions to enable the same scenario.
trans-unit.target: When using Azure Service Bus queues, you can use message sessions to enable the same scenario.

trans-unit.source: Sessions allow you to save and retrieve the application processing state by using the [SetState](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.messagesession.setstate.aspx) and [GetState](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.messagesession.getstate.aspx) methods.
trans-unit.target: Sessions allow you to save and retrieve the application processing state by using the [SetState](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.messagesession.setstate.aspx) and [GetState](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.messagesession.getstate.aspx) methods.

trans-unit.source: For more information about designing reliable multi-step processes and workflows, see [Scheduler Agent Supervisor Pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn589780.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about designing reliable multi-step processes and workflows, see [Scheduler Agent Supervisor Pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn589780.aspx).

trans-unit.source: When using web or worker roles to host multiple background tasks, design your override of the **Run** method to monitor for failed or stalled tasks, and restart them.
trans-unit.target: When using web or worker roles to host multiple background tasks, design your override of the **Run** method to monitor for failed or stalled tasks, and restart them.

trans-unit.target: Where this is not practical, and you are using a worker role, force the worker role to restart by exiting from the **Run** method.

trans-unit.source: When using queues to communicate with background tasks, the queues can act as a buffer to store requests sent to the tasks while the application is under higher than usual load.

trans-unit.source: Background tasks that are initiated by, or otherwise process messages must be designed to handle inconsistencies such as messages arriving out of order, messages that repeatedly cause an error (often referred to as _poison messages_), and messages that are delivered more than once.

trans-unit.source: Consider the following:
trans-unit.target: Consider the following:

trans-unit.source: Messages that must be processed in a specific order, such as those that change data based on its existing value (for example, adding a value to an existing value), may not arrive in the original order they were sent.
trans-unit.target: Messages that must be processed in a specific order, such as those that change data based on its existing value (for example, adding a value to an existing value), may not arrive in the original order they were sent.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, they may be handled by different instances of a background task in a different order due to varying loads on each instance.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, they may be handled by different instances of a background task in a different order due to varying loads on each instance.

trans-unit.source: Messages that must be processed in a specific order should include a sequence number, key, or some other indicator that background tasks can use to ensure they are processed in the correct order.
trans-unit.target: Messages that must be processed in a specific order should include a sequence number, key, or some other indicator that background tasks can use to ensure they are processed in the correct order.

trans-unit.source: However, it is usually more efficient where possible to design the process so that the message order is not important.
trans-unit.target: However, it is usually more efficient where possible to design the process so that the message order is not important.

trans-unit.source: Typically, a background task will peek messages in the queue, which temporarily hides them from other message consumers, and then delete the messages after they have been successfully processed.
trans-unit.target: Typically, a background task will peek messages in the queue, which temporarily hides them from other message consumers, and then delete the messages after they have been successfully processed.

trans-unit.source: If a background task fails when processing a message, that message will reappear on the queue after the peek timeout expires, and will be processed by another instance of the task or during the next processing cycle of this instance.
trans-unit.target: If a background task fails when processing a message, that message will reappear on the queue after the peek timeout expires, and will be processed by another instance of the task or during the next processing cycle of this instance.

trans-unit.source: If the message consistently causes an error in the consumer, it will block the task, the queue, and eventually the application itself when the queue becomes full.
trans-unit.target: If the message consistently causes an error in the consumer, it will block the task, the queue, and eventually the application itself when the queue becomes full.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, it is vital to detect and remove poison messages from the queue.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, it is vital to detect and remove poison messages from the queue.

trans-unit.target: If you are using Azure Service Bus, messages that cause an error can be moved automatically or manually to an associated dead letter queue.

trans-unit.source: Scaling and performance considerations
trans-unit.target: Scaling and performance considerations

trans-unit.source: Background tasks must offer sufficient performance to ensure they do not block the application, or cause inconsistencies due to delayed operation when the system is under load.
trans-unit.target: Background tasks must offer sufficient performance to ensure they do not block the application, or cause inconsistencies due to delayed operation when the system is under load.

trans-unit.source: Typically, performance is improved by scaling the compute instances that host the background tasks.
trans-unit.target: Typically, performance is improved by scaling the compute instances that host the background tasks.

trans-unit.source: When planning and designing background tasks, consider the following points around scalability and performance:
trans-unit.target: When planning and designing background tasks, consider the following points around scalability and performance:

trans-unit.source: Azure supports autoscaling (both scaling out and scaling back in) based on current demand and load, or on a predefined schedule, for Web Sites, Cloud Services web and worker roles, and Virtual Machines hosted deployments.
trans-unit.target: Azure supports autoscaling (both scaling out and scaling back in) based on current demand and load, or on a predefined schedule, for Web Sites, Cloud Services web and worker roles, and Virtual Machines hosted deployments.

trans-unit.source: Use this feature to ensure the application as a whole has sufficient performance capabilities while minimizing runtime costs.
trans-unit.target: Use this feature to ensure the application as a whole has sufficient performance capabilities while minimizing runtime costs.

trans-unit.source: Where background tasks have a different performance capability from the other parts of a Cloud Services application (for example, the UI or components such as the data access layer), hosting the background tasks together in a separate worker role allows the UI and background task roles to scale independently to manage the load.
trans-unit.target: Where background tasks have a different performance capability from the other parts of a Cloud Services application (for example, the UI or components such as the data access layer), hosting the background tasks together in a separate worker role allows the UI and background task roles to scale independently to manage the load.

trans-unit.source: If multiple background tasks have significantly different performance capabilities from each other, consider dividing them into separate worker roles and scaling each role type independently, but note that this may increase runtime costs compared to combining all the tasks into fewer roles.
trans-unit.target: If multiple background tasks have significantly different performance capabilities from each other, consider dividing them into separate worker roles and scaling each role type independently, but note that this may increase runtime costs compared to combining all the tasks into fewer roles.

trans-unit.source: Simply scaling the roles may not be sufficient to prevent loss of performance under load.
trans-unit.target: Simply scaling the roles may not be sufficient to prevent loss of performance under load.

trans-unit.source: You may also need to scale storage queues and other resources to prevent a single point of the overall processing chain becoming a bottleneck.
trans-unit.target: You may also need to scale storage queues and other resources to prevent a single point of the overall processing chain becoming a bottleneck.

trans-unit.source: Also, consider other limitations, such as the maximum throughput of storage and other services the application and the background tasks rely on.
trans-unit.target: Also, consider other limitations, such as the maximum throughput of storage and other services the application and the background tasks rely on.

trans-unit.source: Background tasks must be designed for scaling.
trans-unit.target: Background tasks must be designed for scaling.
